required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Warm Patch Decrease Propofol Injection Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Will Warm Patch on the Injecting Site Decrease the Injection Pain Induced by Propofol

brief_summary.textblock: Propofol causes injection pain is still a common clinical unsolved problem. Mixing a small amount of lidocaine with propofol or injecting lidocaine in advance can reduce the pain caused by propofol injection. Using an air warmer to warm the arm can also reduce the pain caused by propofol injection. Investors suspect that treatment with a warming patch (covering the injection site) can also reduce the pain caused by propofol injection.

detailed_description.textblock:
This is a single-center randomized controlled clinical study. Purpose of this study is to explore whether the coverage of the warming patch (for 5min before injection) can reduce the pain induced by propofol injection.
The patients included in the study were randomly divided into two groups. The group W used a warming patch to cover the injection site, and the group C used a cotton pad to cover the injection site. After 5 minutes of coverage, the propofol injection was induced, and the patient's complaint of pain (calling or arm withdrawal) during propofol injection was observed, and the patient's recall of the pain score during induction after the patient recovered. After the patients regained consciousness, the data of the two groups were compared to determine whether the use of the warming patch could reduce the pain caused by propofol injection.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Group W : the injection site was covered with warm patch. Group C: the injection site was covered with Cotton patch.
study_design_info.masking_description: The assessor did not know the grouping of the pain scores in memory, nor did he know the purpose of the warming patch.

primary_outcome.description: When propofol was injected, the arm was withdrawn due to injection pain.
The patient complained about the pain of the propofol injection

primary_outcome.measure: Pain score after awakening from propofol
primary_outcome.description: Let the patients give a score when they recoved from propofol induced anesthesia.

secondary_outcome.description: those ases when pulse oxygen saturation is less than 90%

secondary_outcome.measure: Temperature of injection site after injecting of propofol.
secondary_outcome.description: Get the temperature of the back of the hand with an infrared thermometer

arm_group.description: the injection site was covered with warm patch.
the injection site was covered with cotton patch.

intervention.description: The warming patch can increase the temp of injection site, result in a blood vessels to dilate, which may have some contribute to decreasing injection pain.
The Cotton patch will cover the injection site as placebo. It dose not have the function of heating comparing to Warming patch.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- No peripheral phlebitis
- No history of Raynaud's syndrome
- No history of smoking or alcoholism
- Body mass index BMI<28 kg/cm2
Exclusion Criteria:
- Refusal of anesthesia
- Previous injection pain caused by propofol
- Difficulty in exposing the veins on the back of the hand or difficulty in venipuncture
- Complained of pain after normal saline infusion.

reference.citation: Jeong M, Yoon H. Comparison of the effects of lidocaine pre-administration and local warming of the intravenous access site on propofol injection pain: Randomized, double-blind controlled trial. Int J Nurs Stud. 2016 Sep;61:209-18. doi: 10.1016/j.ijnurstu.2016.06.012. Epub 2016 Jun 24.

Euasobhon P, Dej-Arkom S, Siriussawakul A, Muangman S, Sriraj W, Pattanittum P, Lumbiganon P. Lidocaine for reducing propofol-induced pain on induction of anaesthesia in adults. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2016 Feb 18;2:CD007874. doi: 10.1002/14651858.CD007874.pub2. Review.

Lang BC, Yang CS, Zhang LL, Zhang WS, Fu YZ. Efficacy of lidocaine on preventing incidence and severity of pain associated with propofol using in pediatric patients: A PRISMA-compliant meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. Medicine (Baltimore). 2017 Mar;96(11):e6320. doi: 10.1097/MD.0000000000006320.
